comment.body:
Hi Evan,
I have an a project with HPE Greenlake and we had a request to integrate with Thales Key Manager system.
Do let me know if you have any concerns.

Thanks a lot for your time 
Remy

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -668,6 +670,7 @@ func NewServerConfig(c *Config, logOptions []log.Option, allowUnknownConfig bool
 	}
 
 	sc.AuthOpaPolicyEngineConfig = c.Server.Experimental.AuthOpaPolicyEngine
+	sc.ExcludeSNFromCASubject = c.Server.Experimental.ExcludeSNFromCASubject

pull_request.title: server: Include CA Serial Number in Subject field
pull_request.body:
This helps avoid running into a crypto/x509 limit that limits how many signature checks are allowed to happen to validate a certificate, most likely to avoid DoS attacks.

Building up a valid certificate chain is done based on the Subject field, even in the presence of an AKID. If all certificates from the bundle have the same Subject name, the verifier will attempt to build up a chain using all of them. Once we have more than 100 certificates in the bundle, we hit that crypto/x509 limit and start failing to verify X509-SVIDs.

Additionally this also improves mTLS channel establishment since we now no longer have to try to build a chain against all certificates from the bundle, we can easily identify the CA that signed an X509-SVID due to it having an unique Subject.

Example resulting Subject:
Subject: C = US, O = SPIFFE, serialNumber = 249778918434805435318471934298663515772

An experimental flag is also available to disable this feature in case there are issues encountered.

**Pull Request check list**

- [x] Commit conforms to CONTRIBUTING.md?
- [x] Proper tests/regressions included?
- [x] Documentation updated?

**Affected functionality**
<!-- Please provide a description of the affected functionality -->

**Description of change**
<!-- Please provide a description of the change -->

**Which issue this PR fixes**
fixes #4415

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -101,6 +101,8 @@ type experimentalConfig struct {
 	AuthOpaPolicyEngine  *authpolicy.OpaEngineConfig `hcl:"auth_opa_policy_engine"`
 	CacheReloadInterval  string                      `hcl:"cache_reload_interval"`
 	PruneEventsOlderThan string                      `hcl:"prune_events_older_than"`
+	// Temporary flag to allow disabling the inclusion of serial number in X509 CAs Subject field
+	ExcludeSNFromCASubject bool `hcl:"exclude_sn_from_ca_subject"`
comment.body: I think this should go in the non-experimental section of the config.

pull_request.title: server: Include CA Serial Number in Subject field
pull_request.body:
This helps avoid running into a crypto/x509 limit that limits how many signature checks are allowed to happen to validate a certificate, most likely to avoid DoS attacks.

Building up a valid certificate chain is done based on the Subject field, even in the presence of an AKID. If all certificates from the bundle have the same Subject name, the verifier will attempt to build up a chain using all of them. Once we have more than 100 certificates in the bundle, we hit that crypto/x509 limit and start failing to verify X509-SVIDs.

Additionally this also improves mTLS channel establishment since we now no longer have to try to build a chain against all certificates from the bundle, we can easily identify the CA that signed an X509-SVID due to it having an unique Subject.

Example resulting Subject:
Subject: C = US, O = SPIFFE, serialNumber = 249778918434805435318471934298663515772

An experimental flag is also available to disable this feature in case there are issues encountered.

pull_request.body:
This helps avoid running into a crypto/x509 limit that limits how many signature checks are allowed to happen to validate a certificate, most likely to avoid DoS attacks.

Building up a valid certificate chain is done based on the Subject field, even in the presence of an AKID. If all certificates from the bundle have the same Subject name, the verifier will attempt to build up a chain using all of them. Once we have more than 100 certificates in the bundle, we hit that crypto/x509 limit and start failing to verify X509-SVIDs.

issue.title: Spire agent SDS does not respond with SPIFFECertValidatorConfig occasionally
issue.body:
<!--
If you are looking for help, please join us on [Slack or the mailing
lists.](https://github.com/spiffe/spiffe/blob/master/README.md)

If you are submitting a feature request or bug report, please be
as detailed as possible.
-->

### Setup
 [Istio Spire integration sample](https://github.com/istio/istio/tree/1.20.0-beta.0/samples/security/spire#integrating-spire-as-a-ca-through-envoys-sds-api) on a KinD cluster


### Observed
When a pod such as the Istio Ingress gateway is deployed after the Spire agent is already present on a node (this is usually the case), the ROOTCA's ValidationContext is **not** `SPIFFECertValidatorConfig`

```
 curl http://localhost:15000/config_dump | jq '.configs | last | .dynamic_active_secrets | last | .secret.validation_context'

{
  "trusted_ca": {
    "inline_bytes": "<redacted>"
  }
}

```

### Expected
The ROOTCA's ValidationContext should always be `SPIFFECertValidatorConfig`. Config dump on the Ingress gateway pod

```
curl http://localhost:15000/config_dump | jq '.configs | last | .dynamic_active_secrets | last | validation_context'

{
  "trusted_ca": {},
  "custom_validator_config": {
    "name": "envoy.tls.cert_validator.spiffe",
    "typed_config": {
      "@type": "type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.transport_sockets.tls.v3.SPIFFECertValidatorConfig",
      "trust_domains": [
        {
          "name": "example.org",
          "trust_bundle": {
            "inline_bytes": "<redacted>"
          }
        }
      ]
    }
  }
}

````
By bouncing the Spire agent, this issue resolves majority of the time.

### Hypothesis
1. When a new pod requests for a workload identity from the Spire agent, it has not been registered with the Spire server. During this period, Envoy requests both the workload and CA certificate. 
2. The Spire agent responds with the CA cert with the correct ValidationContext but not the workload certificate as witnessed in the agent logs ```time="2023-10-25T19:37:17Z" level=error msg="Error building stream secrets response" error="rpc error: code = InvalidArgument desc = workload is not authorized for the requested identities [\"default\"]" method=StreamSecrets pid=11635 service=SDS.v3 subsystem_name=endpoints```
3. Envoy retries until the workload certificate is available
4. The Spire agent responds with both the workload and CA certificate but this time ValidationContext is incorrect because the subsequent requests from envoy do not include the [Node](https://github.com/envoyproxy/go-control-plane/blob/v0.11.1/envoy/service/discovery/v3/discovery.pb.go#L165) property, and this ends up evaluating [supportsSPIFFEAuthExtension](https://github.com/spiffe/spire/blob/v1.7.2/pkg/agent/endpoints/sdsv3/handler.go#L507) to `false`
5. When the spire agent is restarted, it responds with the correct CA cert ValidationContext because the workload pod is already registered.

* **Version**: 1.7.2, 1.5.4
* **Platform**: Kubernetes 1.23, 1.24
* **Subsystem**: Spire agent

issue.title: Spire agent SDS does not respond with SPIFFECertValidatorConfig occasionally
issue.body:
<!--
If you are looking for help, please join us on [Slack or the mailing
lists.](https://github.com/spiffe/spiffe/blob/master/README.md)

If you are submitting a feature request or bug report, please be
as detailed as possible.
-->

### Setup
 [Istio Spire integration sample](https://github.com/istio/istio/tree/1.20.0-beta.0/samples/security/spire#integrating-spire-as-a-ca-through-envoys-sds-api) on a KinD cluster


### Observed
When a pod such as the Istio Ingress gateway is deployed after the Spire agent is already present on a node (this is usually the case), the ROOTCA's ValidationContext is **not** `SPIFFECertValidatorConfig`

```
 curl http://localhost:15000/config_dump | jq '.configs | last | .dynamic_active_secrets | last | .secret.validation_context'

{
  "trusted_ca": {
    "inline_bytes": "<redacted>"
  }
}

```

### Expected
The ROOTCA's ValidationContext should always be `SPIFFECertValidatorConfig`. Config dump on the Ingress gateway pod

```
curl http://localhost:15000/config_dump | jq '.configs | last | .dynamic_active_secrets | last | validation_context'

{
  "trusted_ca": {},
  "custom_validator_config": {
    "name": "envoy.tls.cert_validator.spiffe",
    "typed_config": {
      "@type": "type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.transport_sockets.tls.v3.SPIFFECertValidatorConfig",
      "trust_domains": [
        {
          "name": "example.org",
          "trust_bundle": {
            "inline_bytes": "<redacted>"
          }
        }
      ]
    }
  }
}

````
By bouncing the Spire agent, this issue resolves majority of the time.

### Hypothesis
1. When a new pod requests for a workload identity from the Spire agent, it has not been registered with the Spire server. During this period, Envoy requests both the workload and CA certificate. 
2. The Spire agent responds with the CA cert with the correct ValidationContext but not the workload certificate as witnessed in the agent logs ```time="2023-10-25T19:37:17Z" level=error msg="Error building stream secrets response" error="rpc error: code = InvalidArgument desc = workload is not authorized for the requested identities [\"default\"]" method=StreamSecrets pid=11635 service=SDS.v3 subsystem_name=endpoints```
3. Envoy retries until the workload certificate is available
4. The Spire agent responds with both the workload and CA certificate but this time ValidationContext is incorrect because the subsequent requests from envoy do not include the [Node](https://github.com/envoyproxy/go-control-plane/blob/v0.11.1/envoy/service/discovery/v3/discovery.pb.go#L165) property, and this ends up evaluating [supportsSPIFFEAuthExtension](https://github.com/spiffe/spire/blob/v1.7.2/pkg/agent/endpoints/sdsv3/handler.go#L507) to `false`
5. When the spire agent is restarted, it responds with the correct CA cert ValidationContext because the workload pod is already registered.

* **Version**: 1.7.2, 1.5.4
* **Platform**: Kubernetes 1.23, 1.24
* **Subsystem**: Spire agent

review.body: Thank you @sorindumitru for this contribution, it looks good to me!

pull_request.title: telemetry: allow configuring the inclusion of hostname in lables
pull_request.body:
In some cases this label is not desirable due to it already being added by whatever is ingesting the metrics. For some sink types, e.g Statsd, because due to no lable support, the hostname label is added as part of the metric.

commits.message:
Retain node info on SDS stream when omitted from subsequent requests (#4611)

* Bump the aws-sdk group with 2 updates (#4610)

Bumps the aws-sdk group with 2 updates: [github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/service/ec2](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2) and [github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/service/iam](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2).

Updates `github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/service/ec2` from 1.126.0 to 1.127.0
- [Release notes](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/releases)
- [Commits](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/compare/service/ec2/v1.126.0...service/ec2/v1.127.0)

Updates `github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/service/iam` from 1.22.0 to 1.24.0
- [Release notes](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/releases)
- [Changelog](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/blob/service/s3/v1.24.0/CHANGELOG.md)
- [Commits](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/compare/service/s3/v1.22.0...service/s3/v1.24.0)

---
updated-dependencies:
- dependency-name: github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/service/ec2
  dependency-type: direct:production
  update-type: version-update:semver-minor
  dependency-group: aws-sdk
- dependency-name: github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/service/iam
  dependency-type: direct:production
  update-type: version-update:semver-minor
  dependency-group: aws-sdk
...

issue.title: Spire agent SDS does not respond with SPIFFECertValidatorConfig occasionally
issue.body:
<!--
If you are looking for help, please join us on [Slack or the mailing
lists.](https://github.com/spiffe/spiffe/blob/master/README.md)

If you are submitting a feature request or bug report, please be
as detailed as possible.
-->

### Setup
 [Istio Spire integration sample](https://github.com/istio/istio/tree/1.20.0-beta.0/samples/security/spire#integrating-spire-as-a-ca-through-envoys-sds-api) on a KinD cluster


### Observed
When a pod such as the Istio Ingress gateway is deployed after the Spire agent is already present on a node (this is usually the case), the ROOTCA's ValidationContext is **not** `SPIFFECertValidatorConfig`

```
 curl http://localhost:15000/config_dump | jq '.configs | last | .dynamic_active_secrets | last | .secret.validation_context'

{
  "trusted_ca": {
    "inline_bytes": "<redacted>"
  }
}

```

### Expected
The ROOTCA's ValidationContext should always be `SPIFFECertValidatorConfig`. Config dump on the Ingress gateway pod

```
curl http://localhost:15000/config_dump | jq '.configs | last | .dynamic_active_secrets | last | validation_context'

{
  "trusted_ca": {},
  "custom_validator_config": {
    "name": "envoy.tls.cert_validator.spiffe",
    "typed_config": {
      "@type": "type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.transport_sockets.tls.v3.SPIFFECertValidatorConfig",
      "trust_domains": [
        {
          "name": "example.org",
          "trust_bundle": {
            "inline_bytes": "<redacted>"
          }
        }
      ]
    }
  }
}

````
By bouncing the Spire agent, this issue resolves majority of the time.

### Hypothesis
1. When a new pod requests for a workload identity from the Spire agent, it has not been registered with the Spire server. During this period, Envoy requests both the workload and CA certificate. 
2. The Spire agent responds with the CA cert with the correct ValidationContext but not the workload certificate as witnessed in the agent logs ```time="2023-10-25T19:37:17Z" level=error msg="Error building stream secrets response" error="rpc error: code = InvalidArgument desc = workload is not authorized for the requested identities [\"default\"]" method=StreamSecrets pid=11635 service=SDS.v3 subsystem_name=endpoints```
3. Envoy retries until the workload certificate is available
4. The Spire agent responds with both the workload and CA certificate but this time ValidationContext is incorrect because the subsequent requests from envoy do not include the [Node](https://github.com/envoyproxy/go-control-plane/blob/v0.11.1/envoy/service/discovery/v3/discovery.pb.go#L165) property, and this ends up evaluating [supportsSPIFFEAuthExtension](https://github.com/spiffe/spire/blob/v1.7.2/pkg/agent/endpoints/sdsv3/handler.go#L507) to `false`
5. When the spire agent is restarted, it responds with the correct CA cert ValidationContext because the workload pod is already registered.

* **Version**: 1.7.2, 1.5.4
* **Platform**: Kubernetes 1.23, 1.24
* **Subsystem**: Spire agent

issue.title: FIPS compliant images

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Issues with this label are ready to start work but are in need of someone to do it

labels.name: priority/backlog
labels.description: Issue is approved and in the backlog

labels.name: unscoped
labels.description: The issue needs more design or understanding in order for the work to progress

issue.body: It would be great to build FIPS compliant images for American government agencies and contractors. The scratch image is a good start. We need to meet other requirement like working with FIPS OpenSSL.

issue.title: Spire agent SDS does not respond with SPIFFECertValidatorConfig occasionally
issue.body:
<!--
If you are looking for help, please join us on [Slack or the mailing
lists.](https://github.com/spiffe/spiffe/blob/master/README.md)

If you are submitting a feature request or bug report, please be
as detailed as possible.
-->

### Setup
 [Istio Spire integration sample](https://github.com/istio/istio/tree/1.20.0-beta.0/samples/security/spire#integrating-spire-as-a-ca-through-envoys-sds-api) on a KinD cluster


### Observed
When a pod such as the Istio Ingress gateway is deployed after the Spire agent is already present on a node (this is usually the case), the ROOTCA's ValidationContext is **not** `SPIFFECertValidatorConfig`

```
 curl http://localhost:15000/config_dump | jq '.configs | last | .dynamic_active_secrets | last | .secret.validation_context'

{
  "trusted_ca": {
    "inline_bytes": "<redacted>"
  }
}

```

### Expected
The ROOTCA's ValidationContext should always be `SPIFFECertValidatorConfig`. Config dump on the Ingress gateway pod

```
curl http://localhost:15000/config_dump | jq '.configs | last | .dynamic_active_secrets | last | validation_context'

{
  "trusted_ca": {},
  "custom_validator_config": {
    "name": "envoy.tls.cert_validator.spiffe",
    "typed_config": {
      "@type": "type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.transport_sockets.tls.v3.SPIFFECertValidatorConfig",
      "trust_domains": [
        {
          "name": "example.org",
          "trust_bundle": {
            "inline_bytes": "<redacted>"
          }
        }
      ]
    }
  }
}

````
By bouncing the Spire agent, this issue resolves majority of the time.

### Hypothesis
1. When a new pod requests for a workload identity from the Spire agent, it has not been registered with the Spire server. During this period, Envoy requests both the workload and CA certificate. 
2. The Spire agent responds with the CA cert with the correct ValidationContext but not the workload certificate as witnessed in the agent logs ```time="2023-10-25T19:37:17Z" level=error msg="Error building stream secrets response" error="rpc error: code = InvalidArgument desc = workload is not authorized for the requested identities [\"default\"]" method=StreamSecrets pid=11635 service=SDS.v3 subsystem_name=endpoints```
3. Envoy retries until the workload certificate is available
4. The Spire agent responds with both the workload and CA certificate but this time ValidationContext is incorrect because the subsequent requests from envoy do not include the [Node](https://github.com/envoyproxy/go-control-plane/blob/v0.11.1/envoy/service/discovery/v3/discovery.pb.go#L165) property, and this ends up evaluating [supportsSPIFFEAuthExtension](https://github.com/spiffe/spire/blob/v1.7.2/pkg/agent/endpoints/sdsv3/handler.go#L507) to `false`
5. When the spire agent is restarted, it responds with the correct CA cert ValidationContext because the workload pod is already registered.

* **Version**: 1.7.2, 1.5.4
* **Platform**: Kubernetes 1.23, 1.24
* **Subsystem**: Spire agent

comment.body: I have a few nitpicks but otherwise that seems like a fine, robust approach. If you wouldn't mind opening a PR, that would be great.

issue.title: Spire agent SDS does not respond with SPIFFECertValidatorConfig occasionally
issue.body:
<!--
If you are looking for help, please join us on [Slack or the mailing
lists.](https://github.com/spiffe/spiffe/blob/master/README.md)

If you are submitting a feature request or bug report, please be
as detailed as possible.
-->

### Setup
 [Istio Spire integration sample](https://github.com/istio/istio/tree/1.20.0-beta.0/samples/security/spire#integrating-spire-as-a-ca-through-envoys-sds-api) on a KinD cluster


### Observed
When a pod such as the Istio Ingress gateway is deployed after the Spire agent is already present on a node (this is usually the case), the ROOTCA's ValidationContext is **not** `SPIFFECertValidatorConfig`

```
 curl http://localhost:15000/config_dump | jq '.configs | last | .dynamic_active_secrets | last | .secret.validation_context'

{
  "trusted_ca": {
    "inline_bytes": "<redacted>"
  }
}

```

### Expected
The ROOTCA's ValidationContext should always be `SPIFFECertValidatorConfig`. Config dump on the Ingress gateway pod

```
curl http://localhost:15000/config_dump | jq '.configs | last | .dynamic_active_secrets | last | validation_context'

{
  "trusted_ca": {},
  "custom_validator_config": {
    "name": "envoy.tls.cert_validator.spiffe",
    "typed_config": {
      "@type": "type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.transport_sockets.tls.v3.SPIFFECertValidatorConfig",
      "trust_domains": [
        {
          "name": "dev.otk.twilioinfra.com",
          "trust_bundle": {
            "inline_bytes": "<redacted>"
          }
        }
      ]
    }
  }
}

````
By bouncing the Spire agent, this issue resolves majority of the time.

### Hypothesis
1. When a new pod requests for a workload identity from the Spire agent, it has not been registered with the Spire server. During this period, Envoy requests both the workload and CA certificate. 
2. The Spire agent responds with the CA cert with the correct ValidationContext but not the workload certificate as witnessed in the agent logs ```time="2023-10-25T19:37:17Z" level=error msg="Error building stream secrets response" error="rpc error: code = InvalidArgument desc = workload is not authorized for the requested identities [\"default\"]" method=StreamSecrets pid=11635 service=SDS.v3 subsystem_name=endpoints```
3. Envoy retries until the workload certificate is available
4. The Spire agent responds with both the workload and CA certificate but this time ValidationContext is incorrect because the subsequent requests from envoy do not include the [Node](https://github.com/envoyproxy/go-control-plane/blob/v0.11.1/envoy/service/discovery/v3/discovery.pb.go#L165) property, and this ends up evaluating [supportsSPIFFEAuthExtension](https://github.com/spiffe/spire/blob/v1.7.2/pkg/agent/endpoints/sdsv3/handler.go#L507) to `false`
5. When the spire agent is restarted, it responds with the correct CA cert ValidationContext because the workload pod is already registered.

* **Version**: 1.7.2, 1.5.4
* **Platform**: Kubernetes 1.23, 1.24
* **Subsystem**: Spire agent

comment.body:
Envoy Version 1.25.4. 

I tested this with a patch locally and it seemed to work.

https://github.com/spiffe/spire/compare/main...grameshtwilio:gramesh/sds-patch?expand=1

Not sure if it's the right approach
